Question Text: Which of the following are true about Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The only sizes for an IP address allocation before CIDR were 8, 16, or 24 bits.
b. The prefix length for a CIDR prefix can be anywhere in the range from 0 to 32 bits.
c. In an Internet forwarding table with CIDR, there can only be one unique matching entry for any given IP address.
d. CIDR slowed the rate of Internet routing table growth because prefixes no longer had to be allocated in fixed-size blocks.
LLM Explanation: CIDR allows for variable-length subnet masks, with prefix lengths ranging from 0 to 32 bits. This enables more efficient allocation of IP address blocks compared to the fixed sizes of 8, 16, or 24 bits used in classful addressing. By allowing prefixes to be allocated in variable-sized blocks, CIDR helped slow the growth of Internet routing tables. However, with CIDR, there can be multiple matching entries in the forwarding table for a given IP address, with the longest prefix match being used.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition) by Kurose and Ross, Section 4.1.3', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols (2nd Edition) by Fall and Stevens, Section 2.5', 'RFC 4632: Classless Inter-domain Routing (CIDR): The Internet Address Assignment and Aggregation Plan']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about how DNS lookups work? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. A DNS A-record query for google.com will only return a single IP address at a time.
b. An NS-record query for a DNS lookup will return the name(s) of the authoritative name server(s) for that domain.
c. If your local DNS resolver caches an NS record for google.com for multiple days, all clients who use that DNS resolver will continue using the same IP address to reach Google’s Web server until that NS record expires.
d. An MX-record query for a DNS lookup will return the IP address of the mail server for that domain.
e. All DNS PTR records are maintained by a single organization in-addr.arpa.
LLM Explanation: An NS (Name Server) record query returns the authoritative name server(s) for the specified domain. The other options are incorrect: a) An A record can return multiple IP addresses, not just one at a time.   c) NS records map domain names to authoritative name servers, not IP addresses of web servers. Even if an NS record is cached, the IP address can change. d) MX records contain the domain name of the mail server, not the IP address. e) PTR records map IP addresses to domain names and are maintained by the owner of the IP address block, not a single central organization.
URLs: ['DNS and BIND, 5th Edition by Cricket Liu, Paul Albitz', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_DNS_record_types']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about traffic control with BGP? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. A network operator can use the BGP local preference attribute to control outbound traffic from his or her AS to a destination.
b. A network operator can use BGP AS path prepending to control inbound traffic from his or her AS to a destination.
c. A network operator can use BGP AS path prepending to control outbound traffic from his or her AS to a destination.
d. A network operator can use the BGP local preference attribute to control inbound traffic from his or her AS to a destination.
LLM Explanation: A network operator can use the BGP local preference attribute to control outbound traffic from their AS to a destination. The local preference is used to prefer certain paths out of the AS over others. BGP AS path prepending can also be used to control outbound traffic by making certain paths appear longer and less preferred. However, AS path prepending is typically used to influence inbound traffic from other ASes by making paths through the operator's AS look less attractive. The local preference attribute has no impact on inbound traffic from other ASes.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross', 'BGP: Building Reliable Networks with the Border Gateway Protocol by Iljitsch van Beijnum']
SM - Description: Correct knowledge but incorrect choice selected
Effect - Description of effects: Might try to use BGP AS path prepending to control outgoing traffic
Effect - Error Type: misinformation, peering issue, configuration issues, QoS issue

Question Text: Which of the following are true about layering? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The network layer guarantees reliable, in-order delivery of packets.
b. The network layer has only a single protocol in widespread use today, representing what we call the “narrow waist”.
c. The transport layer uses port numbers.
d. The destination address in the link layer header is always the address of the next layer-3 node along an end-to-end IP path.
LLM Explanation: The network layer has a single widely used protocol - IP - which represents the 'narrow waist' of the protocol stack (b). The transport layer uses port numbers to multiplex/demultiplex data to/from applications (c). The network layer does not guarantee reliable, in-order delivery (a) - that is the job of TCP at the transport layer if needed. The link layer destination address is the address of the next hop node, which may or may not be a layer-3 node (d).
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross, Chapter 1: Computer Networks and the Internet', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens, Chapter 1: Introduction']

Question Text: Which of the following are not true about packet switching? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Once a connection is established between two endpoints in a packet switched network, the end-to-end route cannot change, or the connection must be re-established.
b. Traffic running over a packet-switched network between two endpoints will always experience predictable latency.
c. Traffic running over a packet-switched network between two endpoints will never be dropped by intermediate nodes along the path.
d. A user of a packet switched network might occasionally get a “busy signal” if there are too many users on the network.
LLM Explanation: All of the given choices are incorrect about packet switching:a) In a packet switched network, packets can take different routes between endpoints and the connection does not need to be re-established if the route changes.  b) Latency in a packet switched network is variable and unpredictable as it depends on factors like network congestion.c) Packets can be dropped by intermediate nodes in a packet switched network if buffers are full or errors occur.d) Users do not get a "busy signal" in a packet switched network. If the network is congested, packets may be delayed or dropped but users are not blocked from accessing the network.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_switching']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about content distribution networks? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Content distribution networks can improve the performance that a client sees by reducing the network latency between the client and the content that it is downloading.
b. Content distribution networks can reduce transit expenses for a content provider by enabling much of the provider’s content to be served from a nearby network, sometimes even from a cache that is within the client’s own network.
c. Real-time content such as video streams cannot be distributed from a content distribution network.
d. Content distribution networks typically redirect Web clients to a nearby Web cache by rewriting the IP address of packets sent from the client to the IP address of the nearby Web cache.
LLM Explanation: Content distribution networks (CDNs) can improve client performance by reducing network latency, as the content is served from a nearby cache server rather than the origin server which may be geographically distant (a). CDNs can also reduce transit costs for the content provider, as much of the content is served from edge cache servers, often within the client's own network, reducing the bandwidth usage and cost on the provider's network (b). However, CDNs are commonly used to distribute real-time content like video streams (c is incorrect). CDNs typically redirect clients to a nearby cache using DNS resolution or URL rewriting, not by modifying the IP address of packets (d is incorrect).

Question Text: Which of the following are true about 802.11 wireless medium access control? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Only wireless networks can have collisions at the receiver; such collisions are not possible on wired Ethernet networks.
b. Using RTS/CTS (“request to send”, “clear to send”) control reduces the overall achievable throughput of the wireless network.
c. A wireless sender can avoid causing a collision at the receiver by performing a “carrier sense” to determine whether any other sender wants to transmit at the time that it wishes to send a packet.
d. Disabling RTS/CTS necessarily lowers the effective throughput of the wireless network, since more collisions will occur at the receiver without RTS/CTS enabled.
LLM Explanation: Both options b and c are true about 802.11 wireless medium access control. Using RTS/CTS does reduce overall throughput because of the additional control overhead, but it helps avoid collisions caused by hidden terminals. Performing carrier sense allows a sender to avoid colliding with other transmissions it can detect. Option a is false because collisions can occur on wired Ethernet as well. Option d is false because disabling RTS/CTS can sometimes improve throughput if the overhead of the control frames outweighs the cost of additional collisions.
URLs: ['802.11 Wireless Networks: The Definitive Guide, 2nd Edition by Matthew Gast', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross']
SM - Description: The subtle confusion in this question was the description of the choice. The choice says that carrier sense is used to see if any other nodes wants to transmit. However, carrier sense can only detect when other nodes are indeed transmitting

Question Text: Which of the following are true about video streaming? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Using UDP to stream a video instead of TCP is appropriate if the client is more concerned about low delay and interactivity than it does about receiving a high-quality stream.
b. A larger playout buffer at the client allows the client more time to recover from lost packets.
c. Using TCP for video streaming could result in larger delays between transmission and playout than streaming the same video with UDP.
d. Since UDP provides no reliable delivery guarantees, a video streaming application that uses UDP as its transport cannot recover from any packet loss in the video stream.
LLM Explanation: Using UDP for video streaming is appropriate when low delay and interactivity are more important than receiving a high-quality stream (a). A larger playout buffer at the client provides more time to recover from lost packets by allowing retransmissions or error correction (b). TCP's reliable delivery mechanism and congestion control can introduce larger delays compared to UDP (c). However, (d) is incorrect because even with UDP, a video streaming application can employ techniques like error correction, retransmission requests, or adaptive bitrate to recover from packet loss.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross, Section 7.3', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_media']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about TCP? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. TCP guarantees that the receiver sees the same in-order stream of bytes that the sender transmitted.
b. A TCP sender and receiver use a “three-way handshake” both to set up and to terminate the TCP connection.
c. TCP’s congestion avoidance algorithm causes the sender to reduce its sending rate by a factor of two when it sees a packet loss.
d. A TCP sender controls its sending rate by adjusting the number of unacknowledged packets that can be sent over the network at any time.
LLM Explanation: Options a and d are correct about TCP. TCP does guarantee that the receiver sees the same in-order stream of bytes that the sender transmitted, providing reliable data transfer (a). TCP also uses a congestion window to control the number of unacknowledged packets that can be in transit, adjusting the sending rate (d). However, TCP uses a three-way handshake only to establish the connection, not to terminate it (b is incorrect). And while TCP does react to packet loss, it does not always reduce the sending rate by a factor of two - that depends on the specific congestion control algorithm being used (c is incorrect).
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross, Section 3.5', 'TCP congestion control - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP_congestion_control']
SM - Description: Conceptual issue since TCP does indeed half the sending rate

Question Text: Which of the following are true about denial of service attacks (and defenses)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. If every network on the Internet performed stateless ingress filtering to defend against source IP spoofing, the DNS reflection attack would not work.
b. If every network on the Internet performed stateless egress filtering to defend against source IP address spoofing, the DNS reflection attack could not be carried out.
c. In a “SYN Flood” attack, each TCP SYN packet that a victim receives causes it to set up TCP connection state.
d. A “DNS Reflection” attack requires the attacking client to “spoof” the source IP address of the packet containing the DNS request.
LLM Explanation: Options b, c, and d are all correct statements about denial of service attacks and defenses:b) If all networks implemented egress filtering to prevent source IP spoofing, attackers would not be able to spoof the victim's IP as the source of DNS requests in a reflection attack.c) In a SYN flood, each received SYN causes the victim to allocate resources for a half-open TCP connection, potentially exhausting resources. d) DNS reflection attacks rely on the attacker spoofing the victim's IP as the source of many DNS requests, so the DNS servers' replies overwhelm the victim.Option a is incorrect because ingress filtering at the destination cannot prevent the victim from receiving the reflected DNS replies in a reflection attack.
